description: Sven Halek, troubled by ongoing unrest and the collapse of Council legitimacy, chooses to release Marek Halden’s confidential video confession to the public, overriding Directorate objections.

Halden’s recorded confession is broadcast citywide. In the video, he reveals his doubts about the BCI, describes its harms, apologizes for abuses, and urges an end to prediction-based governance. Emotional reactions sweep Stenograd.
Mass gatherings erupt across Stenograd. Citizens, survivors, and former BCI enforcers share personal accounts of suffering and regret, fueling widespread demands for reparations and systemic justice.
Movement leaders organize a binding citywide vote: whether to rehabilitate a reformed BCI or abolish it entirely. Debate saturates assemblies and public discourse, revealing deep divisions.
The results of the citywide vote are announced—Stenograd is split almost evenly, laying bare enduring rifts but opening fresh dialogue about justice and the future of governance.
